headline: Amazon (AMZN) Q4 2025 Earnings Call Transcript
summary: Joining us today to answer your questions is Andrew Jassy, our CEO, and Brian T. Olsavsky, our CFO.  As you listen to today's conference call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you, which includes our financial results as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter.  Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent filings.

content.title: Amazon (AMZN) Q4 2025 Earnings Call Transcript
content.summary: Joining us today to answer your questions is Andrew Jassy, our CEO, and Brian T. Olsavsky, our CFO. Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC, including our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent filings.

headline: Amazon shares tank on investor jitters over AI spending
summary:
STORY: Amazon shares plunged in after-hours trade Thursday, falling around 11%.

The tumble came after it projected a surge of more than 50% in capital expenditures this year.

The e-commerce giant plans to pump $200 billion into its AI efforts in 2026, joining other tech giants in a spending spree to build out artificial-intelligence infrastructure.

That has some investors worried about returns on the investment. 

Amazon Web Services' revenue grew to $35.6 billion in the December quarter.

While that marked a rise of 24%, the pace of increase was slower than rivals like Google and the figure was overshadowed by the company's capital spending surge.

Speaking to analysts, Chief Executive Andy Jassy said it was easier for smaller competitors to post stellar growth rates. 

But the numbers will concern investors, with AWS accounting for over 60% of the firm's operating profits. 

The results are the latest sign that Big Tech will not be halting AI investments any time soon. 

The top four so-called 'hyperscalers' - Amazon, Microsoft, Google and Meta - are expected to collectively spend more than $630 billion this year.

One analyst told Reuters that "Amazon has to invest at these levels just to stay in the race."

But this week's earnings suggest Wall Street has a message for tech titans: keep spending if you like, but we want to see signs that returns are coming.

That has some investors worried about returns on the investment. 

Amazon Web Services' revenue grew to $35.6 billion in the December quarter.

While that marked a rise of 24%, the pace of increase was slower than rivals like Google and the figure was overshadowed by the company's capital spending surge.

Speaking to analysts, Chief Executive Andy Jassy said it was easier for smaller competitors to post stellar growth rates. 

But the numbers will concern investors, with AWS accounting for over 60% of the firm's operating profits. 

The results are the latest sign that Big Tech will not be halting AI investments any time soon. 

The top four so-called 'hyperscalers' - Amazon, Microsoft, Google and Meta - are expected to collectively spend more than $630 billion this year.

One analyst told Reuters that "Amazon has to invest at these levels just to stay in the race."

But this week's earnings suggest Wall Street has a message for tech titans: keep spending if you like, but we want to see signs that returns are coming.

headline: AT&T Fiber Expansion And Amazon Alliance Put Valuation Gap In Focus
summary: AT&T (NYSE:T) has formed an alliance with Amazon Web Services and Amazon Leo to modernize U.S. connectivity infrastructure. The collaboration focuses on using cloud services and satellite technology to support broadband expansion, including into underserved communities. AT&T has also completed the acquisition of Lumen’s Mass Markets fiber business, extending its fiber footprint to 32 states. These moves mark a material shift in AT&T’s network strategy and service mix beyond routine quarterly...

headline: Big Tech to Spend $650 Billion This Year as AI Race Intensifies
summary: The spending planned by Alphabet Inc., Amazon.com Inc., Meta Platforms Inc. and Microsoft Corp., all in pursuit of dominance in the still-nascent market for AI tools, is a boom without a parallel this century.  Each of the companies’ estimated outlay for this year would set a high-water mark for capital spending by any single corporation in any one of the past 10 years, according to Bloomberg data.

content.title: Big Tech to Spend $650 Billion This Year as AI Race Intensifies
content.summary: The spending planned by Alphabet Inc., Amazon.com Inc., Meta Platforms Inc. and Microsoft Corp., all in pursuit of dominance in the still-nascent market for AI tools, is a boom without a parallel this century.  Each of the companies’ estimated outlay for this year would set a high-water mark for capital spending by any single corporation in any one of the past 10 years, according to Bloomberg data.

headline: Markets Fall Again as Amazon Earnings Heighten Tech Fears. Stock Futures Slide.
summary: Stocks looked set to fall for a fourth day in a row on Friday after online retailer and cloud computing company Amazon reported weaker-than-expected earnings, creating more worries for tech.  The three indexes have been tumbling since Tuesday, when Wall Street started panicking about artificial intelligence usurping software companies.  Amazon failed to ease those fears, as it missed analysts’ estimates for its fourth-quarter earnings late Thursday.

content.title: Markets Fall Again as Amazon Earnings Heighten Tech Fears. Stock Futures Slide.
content.summary: Stocks looked set to fall for a fourth day in a row on Friday after online retailer and cloud computing company Amazon reported weaker-than-expected earnings, creating more worries for tech.  The three indexes have been tumbling since Tuesday, when Wall Street started panicking about artificial intelligence usurping software companies.  Amazon failed to ease those fears, as it missed analysts’ estimates for its fourth-quarter earnings late Thursday.

headline: Global software, data firms slide as AI disruption fears compound jitters over $600 billion capex plans
summary: Global technology and data stocks slid again on Friday, as a rout showed no signs of abating on worries over the impact of powerful ​new AI models on their business and the billions hyperscalers plan to spend on their ‌tech roll out this year.  Amazon shares dropped 8% in premarket trading on Friday after the company's hefty capital expenditure plans deepened investor worries over Big Tech's AI spending spree.  Shares in London Stock Exchange Group also fell further and was set for a second straight week of ‍steep losses.

(NASDAQ:META), attributed the company's current struggles to a long-term shift away from product-led innovation

headline: Amazon shares sink as Big Tech's AI spending plans worry investors
summary: Amazon shares dropped 8% in premarket trading on Friday after the company's hefty capital expenditure plans deepened investor ​worries over Big Tech's spending spree on artificial intelligence.  They also fear that rapidly improving AI tools could eat into demand for traditional software, squeezing profit margins, resulting in a broader selloff across the tech sector.  Amazon's capex ⁠spending plans are expected ‌to reach $200 billion in 2026.

content.title: Amazon shares sink as Big Tech's AI spending plans worry investors
content.summary: Amazon shares dropped 8% in premarket trading on Friday after the company's hefty capital expenditure plans deepened investor ​worries over Big Tech's spending spree on artificial intelligence.  They also fear that rapidly improving AI tools could eat into demand for traditional software, squeezing profit margins, resulting in a broader selloff across the tech sector.  Amazon's capex ⁠spending plans are expected ‌to reach $200 billion in 2026.

headline: Amazon Shares Sink as Company Boosts AI Spending by Nearly 60%
summary: Amazon.com  shares fell sharply after the technology giant unveiled plans for a massive increase in AI-related spending and fourth-quarter growth in its cloud-computing unit that was slower than rivals.  The company said it expects $200 billion in 2026 capital spending, a nearly 60% increase from last year and far above Wall Street expectations.  Amazon shares were about 8% lower in premarket trading.

The company said it expects $200 billion in 2026 capital spending, a nearly 60% increase from last year and far above Wall Street expectations.  Amazon shares were about 8% lower in premarket trading.

headline: Apple Just Had The Biggest Quarter In iPhone History
summary: Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) reported impressive sales growth in the fourth quarter of 2025, even as overall U.S. smartphone sales increased by only 1% year-over-year (Y/Y). Weak low-end and premium Android sales held back overall growth. Apple’s Record Sales Push Market Share to 69% Apple achieved its best sales quarter, expanding its market share to 69%, while Motorola rose to the #1 spot in the sub-$300 category with its new Moto G 2026 series devices, according to Counterpoint Research. headline: The Week in Numbers: Massive stock selloffs, SpaceX mega deal
summary:
STORY: From a massive tech stock sell off to a SpaceX mega deal...

This is the Week in Numbers.

:: The Week in Numbers

:: 11%

11% was the share plunge for Amazon in Thursday's after-hours trade.

Investors sold-off after the tech firm projected a surge of more than 50% in capex this year.

Amazon plans to pump $200 billion into its AI efforts.

It left some market watchers worried about returns and saw the company join a broader tech selloff.

:: 18%

18% is the U.S. tariff rate India now faces - way down from a previous 50%.

U.S. President Donald Trump said he agreed to the trade deal.

He said India would lower its own trade barriers and buy oil from the U.S. and possibly Venezuela instead of Russia.

Trump added India would also purchase more than $500 billion worth of U.S. energy, tech, agricultural, and other products.

:: $1.25 trillion

$1.25 trillion was the value of a merger between Elon Musk's SpaceX and xAI - making it the world's biggest ever M&A deal.

It brings the rocket-and-satellite company together with the maker of the Grok chatbot.

A source said the transaction valued SpaceX at $1 trillion and xAI at $250 billion.

It also comes ahead of a planned IPO this year for Musk's space company

:: 20%

20% was the fall in Novo Nordisk shares after it delivered a gloomy outlook for the year.

The weight-loss giant forecast profits and sales could drop as much as 13% after years of double-digit gains. 

Novo faces challenges including falling drug costs in the U.S. and copycat brands.

This week's projection shocked analysts, who'd only forecast a 2% decline for the Ozempic maker.

:: $70,000

$70,000 is the key level bitcoin fell through this week.

It was its weakest performance since November 2024 when Donald Trump won the U.S. presidential election.

He'd signaled his intention to support crypto during his campaign.

By Friday, bitcoin had fallen as low as $60,000 before bouncing back.

headline: Is Elon Musk Giving Index Funds FOMO?
summary: Buying and holding index funds is one of the smartest things investors can do, but it’s hard.  Owning pieces of America’s largest companies via an S&P 500 fund isn’t exactly the same thing as owning “the market” because some rising stars haven’t qualified for membership yet.  When it looks like they’re about to join, those shares can get a turbo boost right before index funds are forced to buy.

content.title: Is Elon Musk Giving Index Funds FOMO?
content.summary: Buying and holding index funds is one of the smartest things investors can do, but it’s hard.  Owning pieces of America’s largest companies via an S&P 500 fund isn’t exactly the same thing as owning “the market” because some rising stars haven’t qualified for membership yet.  When it looks like they’re about to join, those shares can get a turbo boost right before index funds are forced to buy.

headline: Markets Recovering as Selloff Eases. Stock Futures Pop.
summary: Stocks looked set to snap a three-day losing streak on Friday after online retailer and cloud computing company Amazon’s lofty spending guidance boosted some tech stocks.  The three indexes had been tumbling since Tuesday, when Wall Street started panicking about artificial intelligence usurping software companies.  Google parent Alphabet outlined a plan to double its capital spending late Wednesday, giving the market another reason to fret.

content.title: Markets Recovering as Selloff Eases. Stock Futures Pop.
content.summary: Stocks looked set to snap a three-day losing streak on Friday after online retailer and cloud computing company Amazon’s lofty spending guidance boosted some tech stocks.  The three indexes had been tumbling since Tuesday, when Wall Street started panicking about artificial intelligence usurping software companies.  Google parent Alphabet outlined a plan to double its capital spending late Wednesday, giving the market another reason to fret.

headline: Trump’s Tax Law Sharply Cuts Amazon’s Corporate Tax Bill
summary: Republicans’ new tax law delivered for  Amazon  com, which saw its U.S. corporate income taxes shrink by more than half in 2025 while its profits climbed.  The company’s current U.S. taxes, an accounting measure of taxes incurred last year, declined to $1.2 billion from $9 billion, according to a securities filing released Friday.  Meanwhile, Amazon’s pretax U.S. profit increased by 44.5%, to $89.5 billion.

content.title: Trump’s Tax Law Sharply Cuts Amazon’s Corporate Tax Bill
content.summary: Republicans’ new tax law delivered for  Amazon  com, which saw its U.S. corporate income taxes shrink by more than half in 2025 while its profits climbed.  The company’s current U.S. taxes, an accounting measure of taxes incurred last year, declined to $1.2 billion from $9 billion, according to a securities filing released Friday.  Meanwhile, Amazon’s pretax U.S. profit increased by 44.5%, to $89.5 billion.

headline: Nvidia Stock Is in the Doldrums. Why Amazon’s Huge Spending Might Not Help Much.
summary: Nvidia  is suffering amid the stock market’s tech selloff.  Nvidia shares were up 3.4% at $177.67 in premarket trading.  Amazon said in its earnings report after the market closed on Thursday that it plans capital expenditure of $200 billion in 2026, a nearly 60% increase from last year and far above Wall Street expectations.
